title: Resume - My Data Science Portfolio
text:
University of Data Science
September 2019 - June 2021
- Thesis: Predictive Modeling in High Frequency Trading
- Coursework: Machine Learning, Statistical Analysis, Data Wrangling



Institute of Mathematics and Applications
September 2015 - June 2019
- Graduated with Honors
- Coursework: Linear Algebra, Calculus, Probability, Statistics






Innovatech Solutions
July 2021 - Present
- Lead a team of data scientists to develop machine learning models that increased sales forecasts accuracy by 25%.
- Implemented a data governance strategy that improved data quality and accessibility.



Marketing Maven, Inc.
May 2020 - August 2020
- Assisted in the development of an analytics dashboard that reduced report generation time by 40%.
- Conducted A/B testing analysis that increased customer engagement by 15%.





Programming: Proficient in Python, R, and SQL

Tools: Experienced with Tableau, Excel, and TensorFlow

Languages: Fluent in English and Spanish






Developed a predictive model to forecast demand for a retail chain, improving inventory management.



Performed clustering analysis to segment customers by purchasing behavior, which informed targeted marketing campaigns.





Certified Data Scientist, Data Science Global Association

Advanced Machine Learning, Coursera

title: Data Science Portfolio - Blog
text:
Posted on [Post Date]


Exploratory Data Analysis (EDA) is a crucial step in the data science workflow. It allows us to understand the structure of the data, identify potential errors, and formulate hypotheses for further analysis. In this blog post, we’ll conduct a step-by-step EDA on a dataset about air pollution using R.



First, we need to load the dataset into R. We’ll use the read.csv() function for this purpose:
# Load the dataset
data <- read.csv("path/to/your/dataset.csv")



With the data loaded, let’s look at the first few rows using the head() function:
# View the first few rows of the dataset
head(data)
Next, we’ll summarize the dataset to get a sense of the data’s distribution:
# Summary statistics
summary(data)




Visualizations are an integral part of EDA. We’ll use the ggplot2 package to create some plots. First, ensure the package is installed and then load it:
# Install ggplot2 if you haven't already
install.packages("ggplot2")

# Load the ggplot2 package
library(ggplot2)

# Create a histogram of a variable
ggplot(data, aes(x=variable)) + 
  geom_histogram(binwidth=10)

Replace variable with the actual variable name from your dataset you wish to analyze.



This post covered the basics of loading data, exploring it, and visualizing distributions with R. EDA is a broad field, and there are many more techniques to explore, but this guide should give you a solid start for your analysis on air pollution data.

title: Data Science Portfolio - Blog
text:
Posted on [Post Date]


Exploratory Data Analysis (EDA) is a crucial step in the data science workflow. It allows us to understand the structure of the data, identify potential errors, and formulate hypotheses for further analysis. In this blog post, we’ll conduct a step-by-step EDA on a dataset about air pollution using R.



First, we need to load the dataset into R. We’ll use the read.csv() function for this purpose:
# Load the dataset
data <- read.csv("path/to/your/dataset.csv")



With the data loaded, let’s look at the first few rows using the head() function:
# View the first few rows of the dataset
head(data)
Next, we’ll summarize the dataset to get a sense of the data’s distribution:
# Summary statistics
summary(data)




Visualizations are an integral part of EDA. We’ll use the ggplot2 package to create some plots. First, ensure the package is installed and then load it:
# Install ggplot2 if you haven't already
install.packages("ggplot2")

# Load the ggplot2 package
library(ggplot2)

# Create a histogram of a variable
ggplot(data, aes(x=variable)) + 
  geom_histogram(binwidth=10)

Replace variable with the actual variable name from your dataset you wish to analyze.



This post covered the basics of loading data, exploring it, and visualizing distributions with R. EDA is a broad field, and there are many more techniques to explore, but this guide should give you a solid start for your analysis on air pollution data.
